note: Basic stat blocks only. For mount temperament, breath weapons, living vehicle HP, panic rules, and mounted combat, see the full Saddle & Fang supplement.

vehicles.name: Warhorse
vehicles.desc: Bred for war over generations — bigger, stronger, and meaner than any riding horse. She charges into spear walls without flinching, kicks and bites in close combat, and her rider fights from a platform that towers over infantry. She's the original battle tank.
vehicles.notes: The warhorse is your baseline mount. She charges, she tramples, and she gives the rider a height advantage in melee. Her morale is trained — she doesn't bolt at loud noises or the smell of blood. Compare all fantasy mounts against her to establish relative scale.

vehicles.name: Giant Eagle
vehicles.desc: Wingspan of forty feet, talons that can crush a horse's skull, and the intelligence to follow complex commands. She's not a beast of burden — she's an ally with feathers. She fights willingly, she scouts independently, and she communicates in ways her rider learns to read.
vehicles.notes: The giant eagle is your aerial scout mount. She provides flight, reconnaissance, and combat capability. She's intelligent — she won't suicidally charge a dragon, and she may refuse orders she considers stupid. Use her Spirit die for loyalty checks in dangerous situations.

vehicles.name: Griffin
vehicles.desc: The front half of an eagle, the back half of a lion, and the temperament of something that considers itself the apex predator in any room. She flies, she fights on the ground with equal ferocity, and she bonds with one rider for life. That rider had better be worthy.
vehicles.notes: The griffin is your elite mounted combat animal. She's dangerous in the air and on the ground, which makes her versatile in ways that pure flyers aren't. Her bond with the rider is permanent — she grieves if the rider dies and may refuse another. That loyalty is a story hook.

vehicles.name: Dragon (Young)
vehicles.desc: Twenty feet of scale, claw, and barely-contained fire. She's not yet the city-destroying terror she'll grow into, but she's already the most dangerous thing in any encounter that doesn't involve her parents. She breathes fire, she flies, and she has the arrogance of a creature that knows she's at the top of the food chain.
vehicles.notes: The young dragon is your ultimate mount — and your most dangerous. She has her own agenda, her own intelligence, and her own breath weapon. The rider doesn't control her — they negotiate. Use her Smarts die for willingness checks. She cooperates when she chooses to, not when told to.

vehicles.name: Dire Wolf
vehicles.desc: Shoulder height of a horse, jaws that crush bone, and the pack instincts of a predator that hunts in coordinated formations. She's faster than a horse in broken terrain, quieter in the dark, and her nose tracks prey across miles of wilderness.
vehicles.notes: The dire wolf is your ground mount for wilderness campaigns. She's faster in forests and rough terrain than any horse, she tracks by scent, and she fights with terrifying effectiveness. Use her for ranger-type characters who value stealth and tracking over speed and armour.

vehicles.name: Wyvern
vehicles.desc: A dragon's angry, stupid cousin. Two legs, two wings, a venomous tail, and the disposition of a wasp the size of a horse. She doesn't breathe fire but her tail sting is lethal and she's mean enough to attack things twice her size purely out of spite.
vehicles.notes: The wyvern is your dangerous but controllable flying mount. She's less intelligent than a dragon, which makes her more obedient but less versatile. Her tail sting adds a venomous attack that the rider doesn't control — she stings what she wants. Use her for flying cavalry that's cheaper than griffins.

vehicles.name: War Elephant
vehicles.desc: Twelve feet at the shoulder, carrying a fortified howdah packed with archers, and trained to crush infantry beneath feet the size of tree stumps. She's the medieval tank — terrifying, powerful, and capable of routing entire formations by charging through them.
vehicles.notes: The war elephant is your heavy assault mount. She carries multiple crew in the howdah — a mahout plus archers or spearmen. Her panic weakness remains: Spirit roll when Wounded, stampede on failure. She's devastating when controlled and catastrophic when she isn't.

vehicles.name: Giant Spider
vehicles.desc: Eight legs, wall-climbing ability, and webbing that can immobilise a horse at twenty paces. She moves in absolute silence, she sees in complete darkness, and her rider sits in a saddle between the cephalothorax and the abdomen, trying not to think too hard about what they're sitting on.
vehicles.notes: The giant spider is your infiltration mount. She climbs vertical surfaces, she moves in darkness and silence, and she creates web barriers that block pursuit. Use her for drow, underdark, or dungeon campaigns where conventional mounts can't operate.

vehicles.name: Triceratops
vehicles.desc: Three horns, a bony frill that stops anything short of a ballista bolt, and the charging mass of a freight train. She's herbivorous, which means she's not hunting the rider. She is, however, extremely territorial and will charge anything she perceives as a threat, which is everything.
vehicles.notes: The triceratops is your armoured battering ram. Her frill provides the rider with Cover from frontal attacks. Her charge is devastating — use Strength + Size as collision damage. She's not smart and she doesn't turn quickly, but nothing stops her charge from the front.

vehicles.name: Pegasus
vehicles.desc: A horse with wings. She flies with the grace of a swan, she fights with the heart of a warhorse, and she's beautiful enough to make grown warriors weep. She chooses her rider rather than being tamed, and she'll accept nothing less than a hero.
vehicles.notes: The pegasus is your noble mount — she demands a worthy rider and she won't serve an evil one. Use her for paladins, champions, and characters who've earned something extraordinary. She's a reward, not equipment. Her flight is graceful but she's vulnerable in the air to ranged attacks.
